THEATRE ROYAL, DRURY LAHE
In accordance with the wish that has been frequently expressed, for some account of the local scenery and usages attempted in the revivals and novelties produced, a bill, referring to any particular views or customs, will be circulated, gratuitously, within the Theatre, and may be had on application to the servants in attendance.
DECEMBER 1st, 1842.
DRYDEN'S DRAMATIC OPERA
OF
THE SCENERY BY MR. DANSON.
ACT I.
Scene 1st.—A Saxon Temple, with preparations for the sacrifice to Woden, Thor, and Freya, the human victims.
Scene 2nd.—The British Camp, and appearance of Merlin.
Scene 3rd.—The Magic Fen.
ACT II.
Scene lsf.—Landscape by Moonlight, outskirts of the British Camp.
Scene 2nd.—The Enchanted Wood.
Scene 3rd.—Osmond’s Tent in the Saxon Camp:
Visions of Flora and Vertumna.
And of the Frozen Clime.
ACT III.
Scene lsb—Invocation of the Spirit of Sleep in the Enchanted Wood.
Scene 2nd.—The Enchanted Garden, containing the Magic Tree. Scene 3rd.—Outskirts of the British Camp.
Scene 4th.—British Camp.
Scene 5th.—Pageant of Britannia.

Five Years are supposed to have passed between the Third and Fourth Acts.
Three JYIonths between the Fourth and Fifth Acts.

The Nobility and Gentry, Patrons of this institution, are most respectfully
informed, that
HIS KOVAL HIGHNESS iHE
DUKE OF CAMBRIDGE
*	HAS BEEN GRACIOUSLY PLEASED TO APPOINT
The Twenty-sixth
ANNIVERSARY
WmMTIWvMI^
IN Ail) OF ITS FUNDS AT THE
Freemasons’ Hall
!
FOR
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 15,
WHEN HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS WILL PRESIDE.

STIVAT REGINA.	W. S. Johnson, Printer, Soho.
THEATRE ROYAL, DRURY LANE.
------- APRIL 6th, 1843.
S A P P II 0;
A SERIOUS OPERA.
B V P A O I N I .
ACT I.
The Olympic Cron*«.
Scene 1 st.—The Piece begins before the principal entrance of the Stadium, at Olympia, in Elis, during the celebration of the Olympic Games, at which the Poetess of Lesbos, Sappho, in her contention for the lyric garland, is supposed to sing the late of Antigonus, a Grecian Prince, who, in the desperation of his passion for Temisto had, at the instigation of the Puests of Apollo, thrown himself from the promontory of Leucadia. In her lament for his fate, she denounces the Leucadian priesthood and their rites, as the authors of his death. The plaudits and acclamations of the enraptured multitude ate heard as the curtain rises. Under the spell of her song, the assembled Greeks, kindled to fury, drive Alcander, High Priest of the Leucadian Apollo, with invectives and imprecations from among them. The entrance of Phaon (who, on account of his love for Sappho, had some time before relinquished an alliance with Alcander’s daughter, Climene) furnishes the Priest with an occasion for gratifying his revenge. By accusing Sappho of a preference for Alcjeus, the Lesbian poet, then present at the games, he awakens Phaon’s jealousy and anger against her, and induces him to abandon her, and promise his hand to the slighted Climene. Sappho, to whom the garland has been decreed, is unable to recall his affection, or appease his indignation.—Scene by Marshall.
ACT II.
Thr Nuptials of Phaon.
Scene 1st.—The tiring room of Climene,—who, attended by her maidens, is preparing for the nuptial ceremony. Sappho, who since her desertion by Phaon, has been wandering over Greece in quest of him, attended by Lysimachus, her reputed uncle, implores the intercession of Climene with her father; regarding her misfortunes as a punishment of the gods for her contempt of their priests, she wishes to atone her fault through Alcander’s ministration. Climene receives her, and entertaining for her a sisterly affection, invites her to her marriage, about to be celebrated.—Scene by Telbin.
Scene 2nd.—The Interior of the Great Temple.—Among the youths and maidens assembled at the bridal, Climene introduces Sappho to sing the hymeneal song. On recognizing Phaon in the bridegroom, Sappho re-assures him of her faith ; but being taunted by Alcander with the completion of the nuptial ceremony, she madly casts down the altar, and is driven from the temple by the priests and guests indignant, and terrified at the sacrilegious act. — Scene by Danson.
ACT III.
The Leucadian Leap.
Scene 1st.—The Prophetic Cavern beneath the Temple of Apollo. —Sappho struck with remorse at her own impiety, seeks under the conduct of Alcander, the Priests and Augurs of the Leucadian Apollo’s oracle, desirous of expiating her offence by humiliating herself before the god, and in the hope of alleviating her passion, seeking to cast herself from the sacred rock.—Her prayer being granted, she declares her name and lineage, which being denied by Lysimachus, she is discovered to be the child of her persecutor, Alcander. His endeavours by entreaty arid sacrifice to propitiate the god are vain. The oracle rejects his prayer.—Scene by Telbin.
Scene 2nd.—The Promontory of Leucadia.—Sappho attended by the Priests, and Augurs of Apollo, arrives at the fatal spot, where surrounded by the youths and maids of Leucadia, she sings the nuptial hymn, which she had promised for the union of Phaon and Climene, and at the dawn of day, the appointed hour, bidding farewell to Phaon and her relatives, she casts herself from the rock.— Scene by Marshall.
W. S. Johnson, “ Nassau Steam Press,” Soho.
Theatre Moyai, Drury JLane,
NEVER ACTED.

DRURY-LANE THEATRE.

REVIEW OF THE
LATE DRURY LANE SEASON,
Under Mr, MacrcaJy's management.
The folio win" statement will show the triumphant success of the plays of Shakspeare : themnnber of times they have been represented to full audiences is without a parallel in the annals of the stage, and it is remarkable that nearly ever}’ new play has been unsuccessful. The season has consisted of 183 nights, and Shake-spear has been played 98 nights, leaving 85 nights of other performances
The Shakespeare plays performed, and the number of times :
As You Like It		22 times.
Hamlet		. 7
Othello 		,10
Macbeth 		10
King John		,26
Cymbeline		, 4
Much Ado About Nothing	12
Julius Caesar... 		3
Henry IVth, Part 2	 Winter’s Tale		2
	. 2
	98
PRINCIPAL CHARACTERS PLATE. > BY MR. MACREADY :
Leonates
Virginius
Werner
Beverly
Oakley
Joseph Surface Claude Melnotte Cornus
Marino Faliero
Jaques Hamlet Othello Iago Macbeth King John Iachimo Benedick Brutus Henry IVth
Honour and reverence to Macrea-dy, Shakespear’s attendant spirit! to whom the hearts of all who really love the drama are, “ with an indissoluble tie for ever knit.” He has restored the sublime tints of Nature’s painter, and erased with a delicate but unflinching hand, the sacrilegious daubs, the finishing touches, wherewith a host of Vandals had overlaid him ; he has snuffed out the farthing candles that would light the sun, and placed the pictures of his divine master in their native effulgence after having set them in flames of gold. Since writing the above,
TERMINATION OP MR. MACREADY’S MANAGEMENT.
The house last night was full a3 crowded as on Monday; and if Mr. Macready could not “ lay down hie efficb” without a feeling of pain, it must have been mingled with much pleasure when ho perceived wbat warm friends he had among the London public. At the conclusion of Macbeth the cries for his appearance were most enthusiastic, and though it was some time before he came forward, as he had to change his theatrical costume for a plain black dress, the lungs of the audience did not seem in the least exhausted. When he appeared the storm of applause was suoh as almost to take him off his guard. The house reverberated with “ huzzas,” and the bouquets seemed to fall as thick as hail-stenes. Order af last restored, he delivered the address, which we give below, in a firm voice, but with evident signs of deep emotion, interrupted from time to time by rf newed acclamations, as the public seised on some phrare as affording an opportunity to applaud. The general tenour of the speech, it will be seen, is to show that the public have supported Mr. Macready, and that the immense outlay in putting the theatre in a working condition is the sole cause of his resignation. We had thought otherwise, as far as regards public support, but are rejoiced to be mistaken, as we find that the cause of the drama is not so hopeless as it appeared.
The following is the address
“ Ladies and Gentlemen,—As the present management of this theatre must close to-night, I now appear before you to lay down my office, and give some account of my s’ewardship.
“ It has been currently reported, and generally believed, that the want of encouragement from the public, and the consequently low nightly receipts, are the causes of my resignation. I beg to contradict the assertion.
“ By a reference to my accounts of Covent-garden and Drury-lane Theatres, I find that, even in this year of unprecedented depression and increased taxation, the average of our nightly receipts is only a trifle below that of my last Covent-garden season, which, with profit to the management, paid 7,0001. rent to the proprietors ; and that it exceeds the average of my first Corent-garden season, which paid a rent of more than 5,500k If not at present amounting to a remunerating return, such a result at such a time may, in my opinion, be confidently taken as an earnest of future and permanent success. It certainly has no; discouraged me.
“ The question that obviously arises as to the application of such reciipts is answered, Itbiuk, by the property itself. Upern taking possession I found it—I may without exaggeration say—a poor and scanty collection of lumber. The entire female wardrobe would have been dearly valued at 40k Not one scene fit to be placed on the stage, not even a rope in the whole building to work a scene ! The condition of my occupancy, that.thu theatre should be put into a tenantable state, could uot te fulfilled. A very inadequate sum in annual deduction from rent was allowed towards its fulfilment, and thus the burden ef restoring the various departments of this large establishment from decay and ruin to their present Btate has really fallen npsn myself. I do not urge these facts in accusation of individuals ; but against the law, which gives to persons utterly unacquainted with the drama, and with all appertaining to the dramatic art, an irresponsible power over it, every impartial voice should be lifted np.
“ A brief history of my connexion with the two large theatres (if I do not trespass too far upon your patience) will demonstrate the partial operation of that oppressive law. Covent-garden Theatre, it may be remembered, during my tenancy was raised by public favour from a degraded position into repute and estimation. The treatment I received from its proprietors justified me in applying to the Lord Chamberlain for a personal license—for mere permission to exercise my art—to pursue ray rightful calling without infringement of the law. My application was refused. At Drury-lane Theatre my exertions and my sacrifices have been much greater, and proportionately larger results have been obtained, inasmuch as the drama has been reestablished in this patent theatre, from which the patent-holders themselves had suffered it to be excluded.
“ The principal performers, ladies and gentlemen, have testified their confidence in my system by consenting to hazard one third of their incomes for its support, and I have volunteered still farther sacrifices myself towards perfecting what is so far advanced; bat as 1 cannot subject myself to the liabilities reqnired of me, I have reluctantly and with deep regret resigned my eharge.
“ The consequence is, both these large theatres are now untenanted. The holders of their patents are themselves unable to present the glorious works of Shakspeare to an Eoglisb audience, and yet are armed by the law with power to forbid their representation elsewhere. For were I now, after all I have given and endured to maintain the drama in these theatres—were I, excluded as I am by circumstances, from them, to attempt in a theatre lately licensed by the Lord Chamberlain for performance of the brutes and brute-tamers—were I to attempt there the acting a legitimate play, ‘ the law, with all their might to urge it on,’ would be put iu force to prevent or to punish me! May I not ask for what public benefit sueh a law is framed ? Or for what good purpose it is pet slated ui ?
“With legMdto the prepiwWisef (hit theatre,let m
°®ce	disavow any intention of imputing olame indi-
vidually ; for many of them I entertain the highest resp at and esteem; it is the law under which they act that I complain cf and condemn as the drama’s worst enemy.
44 Ladies and (S-rntImien, I have trespssed 100 long ap-n Tea ; I Wuuli merely add, in concluaio«, that l have en-deav.ured to rede m qve'y phdge of my introductory ad-dreia. I have entitavoured to m^ke y«ur national theatre worthy of Sh*ksp?&re and of our country. In that attempt Jet mo hope that I have not entirely failed. I h^vd at least fetriven nay utmost, and the eucouragem nt X have received Witild havsi be*a sufficient to support me in my t-tniggle, if, aa should have been the case, this theatre had beeu adequately appointed.
44 For tha* encouragement I return yon, Ladies and Gentle-min, my warm acknowk’dgraents. To the reepecable por.ion of the public press lam anxitus to oifer ttie expression of my gratitude f*r its sympathy a».d aid ; and, joining the performers thanks with my ow»*, let me mdulgr the hope that iimo may brag abou. a better state of things, and that I may ya again, tu der tapper auspices, be honoured with y„ur favour and approval.
44 With s rrow, but wtthoat despondency either on my own account or for «he f’.rHma’s cause, X res. ecttully »ni m.tt gratefally take my leave.”
TThewtre	MoyaM, W^ant*.

This Evening, FRIDAY, June 9th, 1843,
